hw_name.description: This is the VESC Logging and Communication Module.

kp0.description:
Pitch Kp0

Pitch kp0 is multiplied by board pitch (in degrees) to determine current demand. If there are no currents defined the board will only use kp0, or else it will scale between kp0 and current1. If kp0 is too high for current 1, the kp resulting from current1/pitch1 will be prioritized.

current1.description:
Pitch 1 Current

The unmodified current output at pitch 1.

current2.description:
Pitch 2 Current

The unmodified current output at pitch 2.

current3.description:
Pitch 3 Current

The unmodified current output at pitch 3.

current4.description:
Pitch 4 Current

The unmodified current output at pitch 4.

current5.description:
Pitch 5 Current

The unmodified current output at pitch 5.

current6.description:
Pitch 6 Current

The unmodified current output at pitch 6.

pitch1.description:
Pitch 1

Defines the pitch where current1 will be applied.

pitch2.description:
Pitch 2

Defines the pitch where current2 will be applied.

pitch3.description:
Pitch 3

Defines the pitch where current3 will be applied.

pitch4.description:
Pitch 4

Defines the pitch where current4 will be applied.

pitch5.description:
Pitch 5

Defines the pitch where current5 will be applied.

pitch6.description:
Pitch 6

Defines the pitch where current6 will be applied.

pitch_kp_input.description:
Enable Pitch Kp Input

Override current inputs to instead read as propotional gain(kp) values such that current = kp x pitch. Any control curve can be made with current inputs or kp inputs. It is a different way to think about it and may be easier to tune for some.

mahony_kp.description:
KP value for Mahony IMU Filter

Decides how heavily the accelerometer is used in "estimating" IMU data. For our purpose, this filter is a bit abused in order to achieve desirable ride behavior.


In practice, increasing this value will loosen up the board, specifically in the center of the board and in how quickly it rebounds to level. If you want a snappier board, drop this down a bit. If you want things a bit looser, with increased board angle control, bump it up a notch or two.


Recommended Values: 1.5 - 2.5 (Caution with higher values!!)


*Note: If your set Mahony KP in "App CFG -> IMU" does not match this value, this value will take priority and writing the Float Config will overwrite this value into your App CFG.

kp_rate.description:
KP Rate

The rate applied to the pitch gyro to modify the current output of the board. Higher values produce a more stable and race-like, while lower values are looser and more playful.

pitch_filter.description:
Pitch Filter

This factor effects the biquad low pass filter applied to the pitch. Lower values will reduce board vibration but also reduce responsiveness. Higher values will more closely match the IMU pitch but more aggressive tunes will experience vibration. A value of zero will disable the filter.

kalman_factor1.description:
Kalman factors

A Kalman filter is applied to the pitch angle to prevent board vibration. Kalman factor 1 is Q_pitch. Higher values will put more weight to the IMU pitch value and track closer to the IMU pitch value. Set to zero to disable filter. Kalman factor 2 is Q_bias. Higher values will put more weight to the IMU gyro value (pitch angle speed). Kalman factor 3 is R_measured. Higher values will act against Q_pitch and Q_bias to provide a dampened response. Values too high will create a noticeable delay in board reaction.

kalman_factor2.description:
Kalman factors

A Kalman filter is applied to the pitch angle to prevent board vibration. Kalman factor 1 is Q_pitch. Higher values will put more weight to the IMU pitch value and track closer to the IMU pitch value. Kalman factor 2 is Q_bias. Higher values will put more weight to the IMU gyro value (pitch angle speed). Kalman factor 3 is R_measured. Higher values will act against Q_pitch and Q_bias to provide a dampened response. Values too high will create a noticeable delay in board reaction.

kalman_factor3.description:
Kalman factors

A Kalman filter is applied to the pitch angle to prevent board vibration. Kalman factor 1 is Q_pitch. Higher values will put more weight to the IMU pitch value and track closer to the IMU pitch value. Kalman factor 2 is Q_bias. Higher values will put more weight to the IMU gyro value (pitch angle speed). Kalman factor 3 is R_measured. Higher values will act against Q_pitch and Q_bias to provide a dampened response. Values too high will create a noticeable delay in board reaction.

roll_kp1.description:
Roll Kp

The roll kp increases the modifies the current demand on a percentage basis to increase output when the board is turning. When the board rolls, roll kp starts acting at (roll angle 1, roll kp 1). As roll increases it will linearly scale to (roll angle 2, roll kp 2) and (roll angle 3, roll kp 3).

roll_kp2.description:
Roll Kp

The roll kp increases the modifies the current demand on a percentage basis to increase output when the board is turning. When the board rolls, roll kp starts acting at (roll angle 1, roll kp 1). As roll increases it will linearly scale to (roll angle 2, roll kp 2) and (roll angle 3, roll kp 3).

roll_kp3.description:
Roll Kp

The roll kp increases the modifies the current demand on a percentage basis to increase output when the board is turning. When the board rolls, roll kp starts acting at (roll angle 1, roll kp 1). As roll increases it will linearly scale to (roll angle 2, roll kp 2) and (roll angle 3, roll kp 3).

roll1.description:
Roll Kp Angle

The roll kp increases the modifies the current demand on a percentage basis to increase output when the board is turning. When the board rolls, roll kp starts acting at (roll angle 1, roll kp 1). As roll increases it will linearly scale to (roll angle 2, roll kp 2) and (roll angle 3, roll kp 3).

roll2.description:
Roll Kp Angle

The roll kp increases the modifies the current demand on a percentage basis to increase output when the board is turning. When the board rolls, roll kp starts acting at (roll angle 1, roll kp 1). As roll increases it will linearly scale to (roll angle 2, roll kp 2) and (roll angle 3, roll kp 3).

roll3.description:
Roll Kp Angle

The roll kp increases the modifies the current demand on a percentage basis to increase output when the board is turning. When the board rolls, roll kp starts acting at (roll angle 1, roll kp 1). As roll increases it will linearly scale to (roll angle 2, roll kp 2) and (roll angle 3, roll kp 3).

brkroll_kp1.description:
Brake Roll Kp

Brake roll kp act similar to roll kp. The difference is that brake roll acts to reduce current output while roll kp increases it. For this reason high values of brake roll kp should be used with caution. 1.0 brake roll kp will reduce current output to zero at the brake roll angle.

brkroll_kp2.description:
Brake Roll Kp

Brake roll kp act similar to roll kp. The difference is that brake roll acts to reduce current output while roll kp increases it. For this reason high values of brake roll kp should be used with caution. 1.0 brake roll kp will reduce current output to zero at the brake roll angle.

brkroll_kp3.description:
Brake Roll Kp

Brake roll kp act similar to roll kp. The difference is that brake roll acts to reduce current output while roll kp increases it. For this reason high values of brake roll kp should be used with caution. 1.0 brake roll kp will reduce current output to zero at the brake roll angle.

brkroll1.description:
Brake Roll Angle

Brake roll kp act similar to roll kp. The difference is that brake roll acts to reduce current output while roll kp increases it. For this reason high values of brake roll kp should be used with caution. 1.0 brake roll kp will reduce current output to zero at the brake roll angle.

brkroll2.description:
Brake Roll Angle

Brake roll kp act similar to roll kp. The difference is that brake roll acts to reduce current output while roll kp increases it. For this reason high values of brake roll kp should be used with caution. 1.0 brake roll kp will reduce current output to zero at the brake roll angle.

brkroll3.description:
Brake Roll Angle

Brake roll kp act similar to roll kp. The difference is that brake roll acts to reduce current output while roll kp increases it. For this reason high values of brake roll kp should be used with caution. 1.0 brake roll kp will reduce current output to zero at the brake roll angle.

rollkp_higherpm.description:
Roll Kp High ERPM Scale

Defines the upper erpm limit that will be scaled by the max scale value.

rollkp_lowerpm.description:
Roll Kp Low ERPM Scale

From zero ERPM to this ERPM value, the roll kp will be multiplied by the maximum scaler. From roll kp low ERPM to roll kp high ERPM the maximum scaler will reduce from its maximum value to 0.

rollkp_maxscale.description:
Roll Kp Maximum Scaler

The maximum scale is used to increase the roll kp response at low speeds. From zero ERPM to the low ERPM scale value, the roll kp will be multiplied by the maximum scaler. From roll kp low ERPM to roll kp high ERPM, the maximum scaler will reduce from its maximum value to 0.


e.g. A scaler value of zero will have no effect. A scaler value of 300% increases roll kp x4 such that if roll kp = 0.5 it will be 2.0 when scaled.

is_surge_enabled.description:
Surge

Surge allows for a burst of motor output when the pitch changes quickly.

surge_period.description:
Surge Period

The minimum amount of time between each surge start. Should be greater than surge cycle. The closer the period is to the surge cycle the greater the risk of instability and loss of control. This has a high level of importance since this will provide a delay between surge cycles.

surge_cycle.description:
Surge Cycle

The maximum amount of time that surge can be engaged. Lower values can give less power. Higher values can cause issues in extreme situations. This has a low level of importance since one of the fault conditions will usually end the surge cycle early.

surge_startanglespeed.description:
Surge Start Angle Speed

This is the nose dip speed that can initiate surge. Lower speeds allow for surge to be initiated more easily. Higher values will require more effort to surge. This has a relatively low level of importance because the actual angle speed can vary quite a bit. We just need a reasonable boundary between normal nose dipping and nose dipping that causes surge.

surge_difflimit.description:
Surge Differential Limit

This is the cumulative pitch required at the Start Angle Speed to initiate surge. This has a high level of importance because it will affect the sensitivity of the surge trigger. A small value can cause nuisance trips in bumpy conditions or initiate the surge too early. A large value will make it hard to surge.

surge_currentmargin.description:
Surge Current Margin

During surge the PID loop is still running and reports the current demand but this demand is not used. As the pitch returns to the setpoint, this current demand naturally reduces. If it is reduced to less than the surge current (maximum continuous current), the surge cycle ends and PID control can resume. The Current Margin is applied to the surge current when compared to the PID demand so that we can end surge later. For example, the surge current is 55A, our pitch is travelling back to setpoint and now demanding 30A. Our surge margin is 1.5. If 30A < 55A / 1.5, we will leave surge. This is true so we will leave surge. In this example, a surge margin of 1.0 would leave surge earlier and at a higher pitch angle and higher current demand.

is_traction_enabled.description:
Traction Control

When a high motor acceleration is detected, traction control engages to reduce current output until traction is regained.

wheelslip_margin.description:
Wheelslip Margin

This is the amount of acceleration the motor has to experience before exiting traction control. Values too high will leave traction control too late and values too low will leave traction control too soon.

wheelslip_accelstart.description:
Wheelslip Acceleration Start

This is the value that defines when the motor no longer has traction and should enter traction control. More powerful motors and batteries will likely require higher values to prevent nuisance trips when rapidly accelerating or surging. For 15s hypercore setups 35 works well.

wheelslip_accelend.description:
Wheelslip Acceleration End

After the board enters traction control the current output goes to zero. This causes a rapid deceleration of the motor. This wheelslip acceleration end defines when the initial wheelslip that started traction control has ended. Now we can wait for the motor to receive acceleration from outside forces to indicate that traction has been regained.

wheelslip_scaleaccel.description:
Wheelslip Scale Acceleration

At lower ERPM the motor is capable of high accelerations. For this reason we apply a scaler to the wheelslip start acceleration value. This value applies linearly, 100% at 0 ERPM to 0% at wheelslip scale ERPM.

wheelslip_scaleerpm.description:
Wheelslip Scale ERPM

At lower ERPM the motor is capable of high accelerations. For this reason we apply a scaler to the wheelslip start acceleration value. This value applies linearly, 100% at 0 ERPM to 0% at wheelslip scale ERPM.

hertz.description:
Frequency of Balance Loop Cycle


Recommended Value: Same or multiple of IMU Sample Rate

  • Little FOCer v3.1 (LSM6DS3): 832Hz
  • Little FOCer v3 (BMI160): 800Hz

fault_pitch.description: Pitch Angle at which a fault is triggered and the board is disengaged. Can help potentially cut-off a runaway board with a stuck sensor (a.k.a "Ghosting").

fault_roll.description: Roll Angle at which a fault is triggered and the board is disengaged. Can help potentially cut-off a runaway board with a stuck sensor (a.k.a "Ghosting").

fault_adc1.description:
Voltage below this value will trigger a fault for the corresponding sensor zone. To disable this switch, set this value to 0.


Hint: If voltage with no input does not settle near 0, consider a pulldown resisitor!

fault_adc2.description:
Voltage below this value will trigger a fault for the corresponding sensor zone. To disable this switch, set this value to 0.


Hint: If voltage with no input does not settle near 0, consider a pulldown resisitor!

is_footbuzz_enabled.description: Beep when both sensors turn off above 2000erpm (beeps for as long as the sensor remains off)

fault_delay_pitch.description: Delay before cutoff, in milliseconds, once a Pitch Axis Fault is detected.

fault_delay_roll.description: Delay before cutoff, in milliseconds, once a Roll Axis Fault is detected.

fault_delay_switch_half.description: Delay before cutoff, in milliseconds, once a Half Switch Fault is detected.

fault_delay_switch_full.description: Delay before cutoff, in milliseconds, once a Full Switch Fault is detected.

fault_adc_half_erpm.description:
ERPM (absoulte value) below which a Half State on the ADC switches (sensor zones) will be considered a Fault.


*Note: ERPM = RPM * (Motor Poles / 2)
For an 11" Tire on a Hypercore Motor (30 Poles):
1000 ERPM ≈ 2.2 mph ≈ 3.5 km/h

fault_is_dual_switch.description:
Treats both sensors as one single-zone sensor (a.k.a. Posi Sensor). Can help guarantee continued sensor engagement, especially at low speed, but disables the Half Switch Fault (Heel Lift dismount) and can present extra ghosting risk if a sensor is stuck.


*Note: For Advanced Riders only!

fault_moving_fault_disabled.description:
Disables ADC Faults completely as long as ERPM is positive (moving forward) and above the Half State Fault ERPM x2, as well as the Roll angle being within 40° of level. Outside of the threshold, the board will not disengage on its own, but rather just default to allowing ADC Faults to disengage the board.


*DISCLAIMER: Requires correct speed calibration and Tail Heavy Board!! The board WILL ghost for sure if your normal speeds read as negative or if your board is nose heavy!!

tiltback_duty_angle.description: Desired setpoint angle for Duty Cycle Tiltback.

tiltback_duty_speed.description: Rate at which nose is tilted back when exceeding Duty Cycle limit (fast tiltback can be dangerous!).

tiltback_duty.description:
Duty Cycle threshold to trigger a safety tiltback (Tiltback raises the nose of the board, informing you to slow down).


*Note: Can be disabled by setting to 100%


*DISCLAIMER: Max Duty Cycle on a VESC is 95%, NOT 100%! Reaching 95% Duty Cycle and pushing beyond WILL result in a nosedive. Use this knowledge to leave yourself the headroom you desire.

is_dutybuzz_enabled.description:
Beep during duty cycle tiltback. It is recommended to disable this beep when enabling the surge beep or else it will be impossible to recognize the surge beep.


Warning: buzzer may not be easily audible at high speeds!

tiltback_hv_angle.description: Desired setpoint angle for High Voltage Tiltback.

tiltback_hv_speed.description: Rate at which nose is tilted back when exceeding High Voltage limit (fast tiltback can be dangerous!).

tiltback_hv.description:
High Voltage threshold to trigger a safety tiltback (Tiltback raises the nose of the vehicle to alert you). High voltage tiltback is most likely to be triggered when braking or going downhill on a full battery, sometimes resulting in a tail drag (take caution!).


Recommended Value: 4.3V * Cell Count (i.e. for a 15s battery, 4.3V * 15 = 64.5V)

tiltback_lv_angle.description: Desired setpoint angle for Low Voltage Tiltback.

tiltback_lv_speed.description: Rate at which nose is tilted back when exceeding Low Voltage threshold (fast tiltback can be dangerous!).

tiltback_lv.description:
Low Voltage threshold to trigger a safety tiltback (Tiltback raises the nose of the vehicle informing you to slow down).


Recommended Value: 3.0V * Cell Count (i.e. for a 15s battery, 3.0V * 15 = 45V)


*DISCLAIMER: Make sure your Voltage Cutoff Start and End (Motor CFG -> General -> Voltage) are below this threshold! LV Tiltback should be used as a notice to stop riding immediately, while the Voltage Cutoffs should be used as a last resort measure to protect the battery.


ALWAYS RESPECT LOW VOLTAGE TILTBACK!

tiltback_ht_angle.description: Desired setpoint angle for High Temperature Tiltback.

tiltback_ht_speed.description: Rate at which nose is tilted back when exceeding High Temperature limit (fast tiltback can be dangerous!).

tiltback_return_speed.description: Speed at which nose is returned back to normal after a tiltback condition has been cleared.

tiltback_constant.description:
Tiltback that will be applied above a configurable minimum ERPM. AKA Nose Angle adjustment, can be downwards (negative) too.


*Note: Should not be used to accomodate tilted rail angle! Instead, the IMU calibration should be adjusted accordingly, either manually or using the IMU Wizard. Otherwise, you will experience the opposite of the desired effect while riding backwards.

tiltback_constant_erpm.description:
ERPM (absolute value) above which Constant Tiltback will be applied.

*Note: ERPM = RPM * (Motor Poles / 2)
For an 11" Tire on a Hypercore Motor (30 Poles):
1000 ERPM ≈ 2.2 mph ≈ 3.5 km/h

noseangling_speed.description: Maximum Rate at which nose will tilt to the desired angle during Constant and/or Variable Tiltback.

inputtilt_remote_type.description:
Select how the remote's reciever communicates with VESC (PPM or UART).


Note: Remote Tiltback requires an input device (such as a UART/PPM Eskate remote)! If not applicable, the type should remain as "None."


Note: For PPM, make sure to keep the Buzzer DISABLED (under "Specs" tab) for proper functionality. A reboot may be required following the switch.

inputtilt_angle_limit.description:
Maximum angle to which Remote Tiltback will tilt. Determines the scaling of throttle-to-angle (i.e. Max Angle of 10° + 50% Throttle = 5° Tilt Angle).


Note: Pitch Axis Faults and Quickstop will be disabled when Remote Tilt Setpoint is beyond 30°, making it safe to use for Vert.


WARNING: Tilting the setpoint beyond the point of nose/tail dragging will cause the board to accelerate on its own (tail dragging forward). Additionally, a high maximum tilt angle can result in unintended nose/tail diving at speed when not used carefully. BE CAUTIOUS when using maximum angles beyond 20°!

inputtilt_speed.description: Rate at which Remote Tiltback will tilt to the desired angle.

inputtilt_smoothing_factor.description:
Determines how much smoothing is added to Remote Tilt, such as when you start tilting and as you approach the target angle.


0 = No Smoothing

3 = Maximum Smoothing


Recommended Values: 1-2

inputtilt_invert_throttle.description:
False:

  • Throttle Forward = Nose Lift
  • Throttle Backward = Nose Lower


True (Default):

  • Throttle Forward = Nose Lower
  • Throttle Backward = Nose Lift

inputtilt_deadband.description:
Deadband region for the center of the input throttle. Can assist with remotes that do not fully return to center.


For example, a Deadband of 10% will only begin adjusting setpoint once the throttle reaches a value of +/- 10%. From there, it will scale as if 10% throttle was the center point (0%).

stickytiltval1.description:
Sticky Tilt Value 1

Low value that will stick first when sticky tilt is activated.

stickytiltval2.description:
Sticky Tilt Value 2

A second sticky tilt value that will only engage after the first value has been activated.

stickytilt_holdcurrent.description:
Sticky Tilt Hold Current

If the current is above this value and sticky tilt value 2 is engaged, it will not switch to value 1 to avoid a tail/nosedive.

is_stickytilt_enabled.description:
Sticky Tilt

Sticky tilt allows the remote to set a persistent offset. Once enabled just flick the throttle in the direction you would like to tilt and it will move to value 1 once the throttle returns to center. Flick the throttle in the same direction to move to value 2. If you flick the throttle in the opposite direction, it will return to center if you are at value 1 or 2. If you push the throttle to maximum it will not activate sticky tilt.

startup_pitch_tolerance.description: Pitch Angle range from "Level" at which the board is allowed to engage. Measured in degrees from Level (0° Pitch).

startup_roll_tolerance.description: Roll Angle (Heel-to-Toe) range from "Flat" at which the board is allowed to engage. Measured in degrees from Flat (0° Roll).

startup_speed.description: Rate at which the board will level itself on startup.

startup_click_current.description:
Strength of the noticeable "click" when engaging.

0A = Stealthy start

20A = Very noticeable click

startup_simplestart_enabled.description: Allow starting with a single sensor, while still allowing heel-lift dismounts. To avoid accidental re-engagement when heel-lift dismounting, this feature is disabled for 5 seconds from the last disengagement.

startup_pushstart_enabled.description: Allow starting the board by jumping onto it, regardless of pitch angle, as long as the speed is 1000 ERPM (~2 mph) or higher.

startup_dirtylandings_enabled.description: Allow landing with an extra 10 degrees pitch tilt within 1 second of disengaging both sensors (not active after heel-lift dismount).

brake_current.description: Brake current to be applied when board is not actively engaged (only applied when an outside force causes motor to move).

is_buzzer_enabled.description: Enable/disable buzzer. Buzzer is controlled by Servo/PPM. Active buzzer required, 3pin version recommended.

disable_pkg.description:
For Initial Setup Only!

Use this option when you need to run the motor wizard or you want to troubleshoot your motor and run terminal commands. Riding won't be possible with this set to true.

version.description: Version of the Float Package.
